newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: U.N. chief speaks to sick Zaire leader by phone.
newsitem.headline: U.N. chief speaks to sick Zaire leader by phone.

text.p: U.N. chief Boutros Boutros-Ghali telephoned Zaire's stricken leader Mobutu Sese Seko, being treated for cancer in Switzerland, in recent days to discuss the conflict in eastern Zaire, a spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

Therese Gastaut, spokeswoman of the U.N. Secretary General at the United Nation's European headquarters in Geneva, also told reporters that further contact between the two men was not excluded. She said Mobutu and Boutros-Ghali discussed the spreading ethnic conflict in eastern Zaire but gave no details.
"It was part of diplomatic efforts. The phone conversation was in the last days -- in the last week or so," Gastaut said.

She said Boutros-Ghali contacted Mobutu at Lausanne's luxury Beau-Rivage Palace hotel where he has been living with more than 20 aides and bodyguards since undergoing surgery for prostate cancer in Switzerland on August 22.
Mobutu himself has not made any public comment on the crisis in the east of his vast, anarchic country which has sent more than half a million Rwandan and Burundian Hutu refugees fleeing.
Humanitarian agencies and Western donors are scraambling to respond to the worsening crisis, which has raised fears about the future of the mineral-rich Central African country if Mobutu dies.
